title: Hitler 'was a SUPER JUNKIE addicted to COCAINE, opiate & meth', explosive book reveals
text:
Hitler 'was a SUPER JUNKIE addicted to COCAINE, opiate & meth', explosive book reveals Hitler 'was a SUPER JUNKIE addicted to COCAINE, opiate & meth', explosive book reveals ADOLF Hitler was a “super-junkie” who could barely function without regular injections of cocaine, methamphetamine and opiates, an author has revealed. PUBLISHED: 01:27, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 | UPDATED: 02:50, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 GETTY Hitler was a "super-junkie" who relied on meth, opiate and cocaine injections 
In his book “Blitzed: Drugs in the Third Reich”, Norman Ohler described the Nazi leader’s insane drug addiction during the final year of the Second World War. 
Hitler was reportedly fascinated with the “heightened feeling” the drugs gave him because it “corresponded so perfectly to his own image of greatness”, according to the Sun. Related articles SS-GB: What is the real history behind the World War 2 drama? 
In a particularly horrific scene, the Nazi leader’s physician Theodor Morell tried to penetrate his veins, but they were so “wrecked” they made a “crunching sound”. 
An extract from Dr Morell’s journal said: “I cancelled injections today, to give the previous puncture holes a chance to heal. 
“Left inside elbow good, right still has red dots (but not pustules), where injections were given.” Good things done by evil dictators Wed, February 1, 2017 Play slideshow 1 of 10 
Although the Nazi leader could barely make his military meetings without the drugs, he was not the only German said to be completely hooked. 
The author notes hundreds of Nazi German soldiers and civilians were high on Perdition, a pill form of meth that promised to “integrate shirkers, malingerers, defeatists and whiners”. GETTY Hitler pictured sleeping next to his 'drug-buddy' and mistress Eva Braun 
Perdition was patented in 1937 and the German public quickly latched on, encouraging the military to order 35 million doses of it. 
The military reportedly liked the “strong feelings of invisibility and power” the drugs provided enabling them to go weeks without sleeping. 
In order to keep up with her lover’s drug habits, Eva Braun took opiates on “date nights” with Hitler. Inside Hitler's Bunker Fri, October 28, 2016 The inside of the bunker where Hitler spent his final days has been revealed for the first time. Play slideshow 1 of 18 
Reports suggested Hitler suffered from Parkinson’s disease during the final days of his life, but others claimed the symptoms were reflective of those from drug withdrawal. 
The author noted: “In his isolation, all pleasure and energy previously received from the attention of a cheering crowd had to be replaced by chemicals.” Related articles
